title: Statement Addresses Concerns About Heart Meds and COVID-19 | Physician's Weekly
content: Based on this hypothesis, the authors suggest that patients with cardiac diseases, hypertension, or diabetes, treated with ACE2-increasing drugs, may be at higher risk for severe COVID-19 infection and should be monitored for ACE2-modulating medications. “There are no experimental or clinical data demonstrating beneficial or adverse outcomes among COVID-19 patients using ACE inhibitor or ARB medications,” Richard J. Kovacs, M. D. , president of the ACC, said in a statement.
